page.lettertext:
fol.128r
May it please yo
r
good L: By a former l
re
written the 17 of
this moneth, I made reporte unto yo
r
L: howe I founde
them heere affected to
e mater of my message.
They have delegated sins certaine persons of their
college, to repaire to
Co: Maurice
and
e
Counsell
of Estate
, w
t
their advise to be assisted in framing
of their answear, These, it is thought will hasten
their retourne, and be heere againe, I ghesse within
these 8 dayes at
e furthest. In the meane seas
o
if either my owne endevo
rs
, or
e travailes of my
frindes had bin able to discover, to w
at
kinde of
course they are secretly inclined, I have used all
my meanes and my uttermost diligence: and
yet I rest as uncertaine as when I came hither.
But if I should imparte my private conjecture,
as I can not well perceave,
at their state is sufficient
to give her
Hig
es
contentation of any good portion, so
I doubt, if it were, there will nothing be obtained,
but by a newe Treatie. For this I finde to be a reason
when
e mater is referred to
e peoples resolution, That to yelde
to any paiment by vertue of
e Contract, were to construe
e Contract to be ended already, and to confesse
at they
are bounde to a present remboursement of all
at
debt unto her Ma
tie
, which I finde by all their hu-
mors is a meere impossibilitie to persuade them to
acknowledge. Heere is at this instant a troublesome
advertisement come from
e Campe, That
e 23 of this
moneth
Co: Philip
going fourth w
t
500 horse, to charge
a watche of
e Enemie of 3 Cornets (upon notice of it
given to
e Enemie before by some spial among us)
in lieu of those 3 he founde at e least 14 and a
1000 foote in ambusche, The charges and [rescues]
and all
e fight of our horsemen was valiantly per-
fourmed, but oppressed in
e end w
t
e Enemies numbers,
were forced to returne w
t
e losse of 40 men, and 70 horse
for w
ch
we had 80 horse of
e Enemie, and 16 prisoners
having slaine by supposal above a hundred: But Co:
Philip himself was grievously hurt, and taken prisoner,
w
t
e younge Co: Ernest his brother, and
Co: Ernest of
Solmes
a very gallant young gentleman, who was also so
hurt, as neither he nor Co: Phillip are lyke to escape it
fol.128v
S
r
Nicholas Parker
in this encounter, is noted to hav[e done]
very singular service. It was bruted heere a [while]
at
de Fuentes
was removed from
e siege of
Ca[mbray]
but this day we have l
re
s from
Abbeville
and
[Calais]
at he continueth very stronge, and doth use [many]
meanes to streiten
e Towne,
w
ch
is all
at I can [signi-]
fie for this p
nt
to your L: and so I take my
humble leave.
Hage 27 Au
g
95
